current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To reduce prescription drug misuse and
		  abuse.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

committee-name.#text: Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions

short-title.#text:
Increasing the Safety of
			 Prescription Drug Use Act of 2013

text.#text:
any person who

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 399O of the Public Health Service Act

header.#text:
Requirements
				for Federal health care programs

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: (referred to in this subsection as the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Secretary of Health and Human Services

quote.#tail:
) shall award grants to one or more States to
				carry out a 1-year pilot project to develop a standardized peer review process
				and methodology to review and evaluate prescribing and pharmacy dispensing
				patterns, through a review of prescription drug monitoring programs (referred to in this section as

) in the
				States receiving such grants.

text.#text:
The
				recipients of a grant under this section shall develop a systematic,
				standardized methodology to identify and investigate questionable or
				inappropriate prescribing and dispensing patterns of substances on schedule II
				or III under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
. Such peer review
				methodology and prescribing and dispensing patterns shall be shared with the appropriate State health
				profession board.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 202 of the Controlled Substances Act

text.#text:
A
				State receiving a grant under this section shall—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
in order to prescribe such controlled substances, make the
				information with respect to such controlled substances from the PDMP available to State
				regulation and licensing boards; and

with respect to
				controlled substances  for which a prescriber is required to have a license issued by the

with respect to
				any other controlled substances, may make the information with respect to such controlled substances from the
				PDMP available to State regulation and licensing boards.

may serve as the

text.#text:
A
				quality improvement organization with which the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
is amended by adding at the end
			 the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Part P of title III of
			 the Public Health Service Act

header.#text:
Prescription
			 drug and other controlled substance abuse prevention

Prescription
				drug and other controlled substance abuse prevention

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall award 5-year grants to eligible
				entities to facilitate training in order to increase the capacity of health
				care providers to conduct patient screening and brief interventions, such as in health
				care settings to prevent the abuse of prescription drugs and other controlled substances. The grant program under this section may be coordinated with the Screening Brief Intervention and Referral to Treatment grant program of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration

text.#text:
continuing
				education entities, such as health profession boards or health accrediting
				bodies; and

other appropriate
				health or professional education organizations or institutions.

Health care providers who participate in or are
				employed by a Federal health care program, including the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
title XVIII of the Social
				Security Act

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, the State Children's Health
				Insurance Program under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
title XIX of
				the Social Security Act

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, and Federally qualified health centers, shall screen patients for
				abuse of prescription drugs or other controlled substances, conduct brief interventions, and provide referrals for
				known or suspected abuse of prescription drugs or other controlled substances, as appropriate.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: title XXI of the Social Security Act

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, shall award grants to States for
				the purpose of evaluating the prospect of the health professions board of such
				States reviewing and expanding prescribing authorities of providers,
				such as advance practice nurses and physician's assistants, in order to
				control the abuse of prescription drugs or other controlled substances with respect to specific drugs and other controlled substances, as
				appropriate.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Administrator of the
				Health Resources and Services Administration

header.#text:
Prescription
			 drug abuse training and screening programs

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: (referred to in this section as the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Secretary of Health and Human Services

section 202 of the
			 Controlled Substances Act

quote.#tail:
) shall award
			 grants to States to develop continuing education criteria and review processes
			 that allow State health profession boards or State agencies to certify
			 appropriate education and training for informed and safe prescribing of opioids
			 and other drugs on schedule II and III under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
that such
			 practitioner has completed continuing medical education—

text.#text:
A practitioner who registers or renews a registration
			 under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall,
			 at the time of registering, certify to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 303(f) of the Controlled Substances Act

text.#text:
in the case of a
			 practitioner registering for the first time, with respect to prescription drug
			 abuse; and

in the case of a
			 practitioner renewing a registration, with respect to medical understanding of
			 the proper use of all drugs listed in the schedules under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 202 of the
			 Controlled Substances Act

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall require that a practitioner
			 registered under

conduct patient screening for potential drug misuse or
			 abuse before prescribing a drug listed on schedule II or III under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 303(f) of the Controlled Substances Act

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , according to standards established by the applicable State licensing body.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 202
			 of the Controlled Substances Act

Secretary of
			 Health and Human Services

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
,
			 shall conduct a review of naloxone to consider whether naloxone should cease to
			 be subject to

and be available as a behind-the-counter drug, in order to increase
			 access of such drug to community-based organizations and street outreach
			 organizations.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 503(b) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act/s:503/ss:b

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall convene or coordinate with an existing  entity an interagency working group to
			 encourage States and local governments to increase opportunities for disposal
			 of opiates, such as frequent
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Secretary of
			 Health and Human Services

quote.#tail:
and fixed
			 medicine disposal sites at law enforcement public buildings, and to reduce
			 opportunities for abuse of opiates, such as establishing opioid dispensing
			 limits at hospital emergency departments.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall review prescription drug abuse programs and policies
			 in Federal agencies and best practices with respect to prescription drug abuse
			 programs of the States and, not later than 18 months after the date of
			 enactment of this Act, shall issue a report to
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Comptroller General
			 of the United States

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
on its findings and
			 recommendations on ways to reduce prescription drug abuse.
